head.title: For Teen-Agers, Tobacco Is a Gateway Drug

hedline.hl1: For Teen-Agers, Tobacco Is a Gateway Drug

abstract.p: Peter Buenida letter agrees with August 20 editorial, which found Federal appeals court ruling denying FDA authority to regulate or prohibit tobacco sales to children ignored fact that nicotine is addictive drug (S)

block.p: Re ''A Shortsighted Tobacco Decision'' (editorial, Aug. 20): I find it interesting that a Federal appeals court ruled that the Food and Drug Administration does not have the authority to regulate tobacco or prohibit tobacco sales to children after the Senate surrendered to the tobacco industry by failing to pass the McCain bill. You are right in pointing out that the decision in this case ignored the fact that nicotine is an addictive drug.

Re ''A Shortsighted Tobacco Decision'' (editorial, Aug. 20): I find it interesting that a Federal appeals court ruled that the Food and Drug Administration does not have the authority to regulate tobacco or prohibit tobacco sales to children after the Senate surrendered to the tobacco industry by failing to pass the McCain bill. You are right in pointing out that the decision in this case ignored the fact that nicotine is an addictive drug.

In fact, independent researchers say that nicotine is just as addictive as heroin and cocaine. Common sense would suggest that the F.D.A. should have the authority to regulate cigarettes as drug-delivery devices under the Food, Drug and Cosmetics Act. Besides, the food and drug agency should also have the authority to regulate the sales of cigarettes to children, because tobacco smoke contains lethal chemicals like carbon monoxide, benzopyrene and hydrogen cyanide.
